subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Creating a Diverse and Inclusive Workplace Culture
headline: This free online course explores the fundamental concepts and value of creating an inclusive and diverse workplace.
description: This short course explains the importance of setting up a diverse workgroup, how you can achieve it and its benefits. You will discover the reasons behind gender bias among other biases in the workplace and how to overcome it. You will also uncover essential qualities of a conducive work environment and how to manage the uniqueness of each individual as a fellow employee or as an employer. So sign up for this course and start learning.
courseDescription:
There is beauty in diversity that leads to strength and accomplishments. Sadly, some workplaces don't possess the ethics that create room for such diversity and inclusiveness. They sideline many of those who would have contributed helpful concepts. As a result, companies lose good ideas and inputs that would have enhanced their productivity. Overall success is lost, depriving the company of the degree of growth it would have attained. This course details how this much-needed diversity and inclusiveness can be created or restored.

This course describes the value of a diverse, equitable and inclusive workplace. Next, it highlights the need to include variations in social identities like gender, race, age, sexual orientation, ability and class. It further presents the need to ensure that the rules that govern a workplace and the systems it takes part in are created to benefit everyone - not just a select few. Finally, it spotlights the essence of valuing the perspectives and contributions of everyone and incorporating their needs and views into the company's activities. 

However, some workplace biases are intentional but others happen subliminally. Rooting out these conscious and unconscious biases helps build the right team and sets good standards and practices for a company. This will in turn help to produce better marketing, foster creative thinking, promote innovation and contribute to the overall team spirit. So enrol in this course right away and learn to enhance your company's productivity.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Define workplace diversity, equity and inclusiveness.
    • Evaluate your workplace culture with respect to diversity, equity and inclusiveness.
    • Identify the importance of precise language within a workplace.
    • Explain what unconscious bias is and how it can impede inclusiveness in your workplace.
    • Outline the benefits of overcoming unconscious bias in a workplace.
    • Discuss gender bias and its effect in the workplace.
    • Recognize the benefits of being inclusive in a workplace when holding meetings. 

  • Introduction to the Workplace Environment

  • Imagine your ideal workplace. Specifically, think about all the different people who work there, from the newest recruit to the founder or CEO. 

    Think about how everyone got to where they are, what their titles are, and how they might advance at work.

    What does opportunity look like for them? What role do they play in the workplace culture?

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • In order to create a more diverse, equitable, and inclusive workplace, it’s important to understand the terms. Put simply, what do we mean by the words diversity, equity, and inclusion? These terms will be discussed in the following pages.

  • In order to create a more diverse, equitable, and inclusive workplace, it’s important to understand the terms. Put simply, what do we mean by the words diversity, equity, and inclusion? These terms will be discussed in the following pages. 

  • Creating a Good Workplace Environment

  • Workplaces should be places where diverse backgrounds and opinions are valued and where everyone feels both included and equal. Getting a diverse set of opinions voiced is important for the success of any business. It helps you take the hard looks at your business that you need to in order to survive.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Diverse, inclusive workplaces also mean better workplace environments, which can attract better employees and do more to contribute to their communities.

    So, what does a good workplace environment look like?
  • One key way to create a workplace where everyone feels welcome is to use accurate, empowering, and inclusive language, AKA precise language.

    This is especially true when talking about race, gender, and other social constructs.

  • Understanding Unconscious Bias

  • For the most part, we know what we like and don’t like. 

    We prefer this type of food over another type of food.

    We love this song but can’t stand this other song.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Being conscious of our likes and dislikes can help us make informed decisions. But sometimes our likes and dislikes are the reasons our decisions aren’t so cut-and-dried.

    Unconscious bias is normal. Everyone experiences it, and it happens naturally without us knowing it. 

    Unconscious bias occurs when deep-seated attitudes and beliefs–which stem from our backgrounds, the cultures we were raised in, our life experiences, and other personal factors–influence our actions and decisions.

  • Gender Bias—Case Study

  • Imagine Bruna and Bruno are pilots for Fair & Square Air, an airline that tries to stand out from its competitors by treating customers more fairly. The airline promotes its fair fares, free checked bags, and full refunds for cancelled flights. But they’re not as fair and square with their employees.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Bruno gets paid 25% more than Bruna for the same work.

    Bruna and Bruno started at the same time, have logged similar hours, and have both received strong performance reviews.

    On paper, the only difference is the last letter in their names.
    So why do you think Bruno makes more?
  • Bruna’s lower salary is an example of workplace gender inequality. It can often happen when people in management act on their biases, even unintentionally.

    Gender bias is when men are given better employment opportunities than women.
    Fair & Square Air is showing its gender bias (and failing to live up to its name) by paying equally-qualified women pilots less than men.

  • Gender Bias—Case Study

    Bruna and Bruno started at the same time, have logged similar hours, and have both received strong performance reviews.

    On paper, the only difference is the last letter in their names.
    So why do you think Bruno makes more?
  • Bruna’s lower salary is an example of workplace gender inequality. It can often happen when people in management act on their biases, even unintentionally.

    Gender bias is when men are given better employment opportunities than women.
    Fair & Square Air is showing its gender bias (and failing to live up to its name) by paying equally-qualified women pilots less than men.

  • Gender Bias—Case Study

  • Imagine Bruna and Bruno are pilots for Fair & Square Air, an airline that tries to stand out from its competitors by treating customers more fairly. The airline promotes its fair fares, free checked bags, and full refunds for cancelled flights. But they’re not as fair and square with their employees.

  • How to Conduct Inclusive Meetings

  • Imagine Too Good Tour Guides, a business that offers private tours by guides who are practically too good to be true. Say Too Good Tour Guides have to have a meeting to plan their spring tour schedule.

    It’s a big decision that affects everyone, so everyone has been invited to the meeting. The staff’s been invited, and the meeting’s been booked.

    Now how can Too Good Tour Guides use this meeting to generate ideas and make decisions that work for everyone?
    Let’s decide. Multiple choice question:
  • Which of these would more likely generate ideas and positive outcomes?
    • The boss says what she wants and everyone silently nods in agreement.
    • Everyone gets a chance to talk and listen, even if not everything that is said is agreed upon.
  • In most businesses, meetings are central to how things get done, and getting a diverse set of opinions voiced in these meetings is important for success.

  • Lesson Summary

  • In this module, you have learned that:
    • Diversity refers to differences and variations within a group. This can include variations in social identities like gender, race, age, sexual orientation, ability, and class. It can also include variations in personal attributes like expertise, values, worldview, mindset, and experiences.
    • Equity means all individuals have access, opportunities, and success, regardless of social or cultural factors.
    • Inclusiveness means valuing the perspectives and contributions of a wide range of people and incorporating their needs and views into all you do.
    • Precise language is one tool you can use to create an environment that leads to more diversity, equity, and inclusion in your workplace.
    • Removing unconscious bias can help you produce better marketing, develop more creative ideas, find better ways to reach your customers, and build more innovative products.
    • To generate ideas and make decisions that work for everyone, everyone should get a chance to talk and listen, even if not everything that is said is agreed upon.
